questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the anatomy of the liver?

choices.text: Cantlie's line divides the liver functionally into two hemi-livers
The liver has 2 major and 2 minor fissures.
Three main hepatic veins divide the liver into four portal sectors
Each Couinaud's segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

questions.solution:
The liver has 3 major and 3 minor fissures. 

The major portal fissures (are not visible on the liver surface and run through the parenchyma)

  • Middle/main portal fissure (Cantlie's line)
    • extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver back to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava.
    • Contains the middle hepatic vein
    • Separates the liver into the right and left hemi-livers.
  • Right portal fissure
    • Contains the right hepatic vein
    • Divides the liver into the right anterior/medial sector (segments V and VIII) and right posterior/lateral sector (segments VI and VII).
  • Left portal fissure
    • Contains the left hepatic vein
    • Separates the left anterior/medial (segments IV) and left posterior/lateral sectors (Segment II and III)

 The three minor fissures (are visible as physical clefts of the liver surface) 

  • Umbilical fissure or fissure for the ligamentum teres
  • Venous fissure or fissure for the ligamentum venosum
  • Fissure of gans or Rouvière’s sulcus

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: A young patient presents with distension of the abdomen and yellowish discoloration of the eyes for the past 6 months.  After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver. The surgeon decides to perform a left hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments has to be removed in the patient?
questions.solution:
In the left hemi-hepatectomy (also called left hepatectomy) the segments marked as II, III, and IV should be removed.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver is divided into eight segments. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. Segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver.

questions.text: What is the most common anomaly of the hepatic artery?

choices.text: Independent origin of the right and left hepatic arteries from the cealic axis
Replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesentric artery

questions.solution:
The most common anomaly of the hepatic artery is replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesenteric artery. 

Normally, the common hepatic artery gives off the right and left hepatic arteries. A middle hepatic artery branches off from the proximal left hepatic artery.

The replaced right hepatic artery directly supplies the right lobe of the liver.

Surgical significance: 

In individuals with replaced right hepatic artery, the diameter of the common hepatic artery is smaller. In liver transplant recipients, this can be a cause for the increased incidence of complications such as thrombosis.

Whereas, replaced right hepatic artery is a beneficial variant for donors undergoing donation of the right lobe of the liver. The replaced right hepatic artery provides a longer and larger graft thus reducing chances of thrombosis.

questions.text: The free hepatic venous pressure(FHVP) and wedged hepatic venous pressure(WHVP) of a patient, with suspected portal hypertension, are measured. How will the hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) be determined from these values?
questions.solution:
Hepatic Venous Pressure Gradient is measured by subtracting Free Hepatic Venous Pressure from Wedged Hepatic Venous Pressure.

HVPG = WHVP – FHVP

Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the pressure gradient between the portal vein and the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is a measure of portal venous pressure. It can quantify the degree of portal hypertension due to sinusoidal resistance to blood flow.

The most accurate method of determining portal hypertension is by measuring HVPG. The most commonly used procedure involves placing a balloon catheter in the hepatic vein after a jugular vein puncture. The free hepatic venous pressure (FHVP) is measured with the balloon deflated, and the wedged hepatic venous pressure (WHVP) with the balloon inflated to occlude the hepatic vein.

questions.text: Which of the following values indicate a normal portal venous pressure?
questions.solution:
The normal portal venous pressure is 5 to 10 mmHg. 

Normal portal blood flow is 1 to 1.5 L/minute.

Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the difference between the wedge and free hepatic venous pressure, which is 1 to 5 mmHg.

HVPG interpretation:

  • Normal HVPG is between 1 and 5 mmHg.
  • Portal hypertension is present if the HVPG is ≥6 mmHg.
  • Portal hypertension typically becomes clinically significant when the HVPG is ≥10 mmHg, at which point varices may develop.
  • HVPG ≥12 mmHg, patients are at risk for variceal bleeding and the development of ascites.

questions.text:
All of the following are post-hepatic causes for portal hypertension, except_____
  1. Budd Chiari syndrome
  2. Splenomegaly
  3. Chronic right-sided cardiac congestion
  4. Sarcoidosis
  5. Primary biliary cholangitis
questions.solution:
Splenomegaly is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension. Sarcoidosis and primary biliary cholangitis are presinusoidal intrahepatic causes of portal hypertension.

Portal hypertension occurs when the pressure in the portal vein increases due to either increased resistance to blood flow secondary to fibrosis, active vasoconstriction, or hyperdynamic systemic circulation.

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of chronic pancreatitis is diagnosed with splenic vein thrombosis. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: USG abdomen showed normal liver and an enlarged spleen.
TIPSS is done as part of  treatment

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a case of splenic vein thrombosis which can cause left-sided portal hypertension. It is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension. It is managed by splenectomy. 

Splenic vein thrombosis can be due to pancreatic inflammation or neoplasms (acute or chronic pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and carcinomas) that extend outside the pancreas and invades the splenic vein. This causes increased pressure in the splenic vein leading to the formation of collaterals and ultimately gastric variceal hemorrhage (not esophageal varices).

Normal liver function tests, normal portal venous pressures, and splenomegaly are the distinguishing features from other forms of portal hypertension. The portal vein pressures remain normal as there is no obstruction of the hepatic venous vasculature.

Diagnosis is done by gastroscopy, liver function tests, ultrasound examination (with doppler), and contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. Treatment includes splenectomy and management of the primary pancreatic pathology.

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: An elderly patient with chronic black tarry stools underwent an upper GI endoscopy. Gastric mucosa appeared as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the snake-skin appearance of the gastric mucosa, which is seen in cases of portal hypertensive gastropathy.

Portal hypertensive gastropathy is characterized by the diffuse dila­tion of the mucosal and submucosal venous plexus of the stomach associated with overlying gastritis.

Option A: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) also known as watermelon stomach is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly, characterized endoscopically by watermelon stripes. It is associated with heterogeneous medical conditions, including hepatic, cardiac, and renal diseases.

Option C: Hypoproteinemic hypertrophic gastropathy also known as Menetrier's disease is a rare, acquired premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, little or no acid production, and excessive mucous production with resultant protein loss. The disorder is associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor-alpha.

Option D: Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a large tortuous arteriole that erodes and bleeds and occurs most commonly in the stomach wall.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Budd-Chiari syndrome?

choices.text: Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in approximately 50% of the patients
Doppler ultrasonography is the initial investigation of choice
It becomes clinically significant when one or more major hepatic veins are obstructed
Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor

questions.solution:
Budd–Chiari syndrome (BCS) is an uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow and it becomes clinically significant when two or more major hepatic veins are obstructed.

Types: 

  • Primary  Budd–Chiari syndrome: when the obstructive process involves an endoluminal venous thrombosis.
  • Secondary Budd–Chiari syndrome:  when the veins are compressed or invaded by a neighboring lesion originating outside the vein.

Most common presentation: ascites and abdominal discomfort.

Risk factors include-Primary myeloproliferative disorders, anticardiolipin antibodies, hyperhomocysteinemia, and oral contraceptive use.

Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in approximately 50% of the cases and it is because the caudate lobe drains directly into the IVC.

Abdominal ultrasonography with color Doppler is the initial investigation of choice and can demonstrate the absence of hepatic vein flow, spider web hepatic veins, and collateral hepatic veins.

The definitive radiographic study is hepatic venography to determine the presence and extent of hepatic vein thrombus as well as measure inferior vena cava (IVC) pressures.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and distension for the past 3 months. Her past medical records show that she has a JAK2 mutation and investigations revealed serum protein to be 3 g/dL and ascitic fluid protein to be 1.5 g/dL. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Anticoagulation is the mainstay of treatment
Colour flow doppler is the initial investigation of choice
Surgical intervention is done in all cases
Ascites is a bad prognostic factor

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario describes a case of late budd-chiari syndrome and surgical interventions are not done in all cases of budd chiari syndrome.

SAAG = (serum albumin) − (ascitic fluid albumin)

         = (3) - (1.5) = 1.5g/dL

As SAAG is >1.1g/dL( 1.5g/dL) and ascitic fluid protein is < 2.5 g/dL, the most likely cause is late Budd-Chiari syndrome.Surgical interventions are done in those patients of Budd Chiari syndrome who are not responding to medical therapy.

Colour flow doppler is the initial investigation of choice.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment consists of medically managing the underlying disease process and preventing the extension of the hepatic vein thrombosis through systemic anticoagulation.
  • The associated portal hypertension and ascites are managed in a manner similar to that in most cirrhotic patients.
  • Radiologic and surgical intervention should be reserved for patients whose condition is nonresponsive to medical therapy. Percutaneous angioplasty and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS), in combination with thrombolytic therapy, are the preferred strategies to restore the outflow of blood from the liver.
  • Surgical shunting, particularly with the side-to-side portacaval shunt,  turns the portal vein into a hepatic outflow tract.

Factors contributing to a bad prognosis in Budd-Chiari syndrome:

  • Involvement of all three hepatic veins and/or portal vein
  • Presence of ascites
  • Older age at the time of presentation
  • High Child-Pugh score
  • Chronic disease at presentation

Note: JAK2 mutation points to a possibility of polycythemia vera predisposing the patient to hypercoagulable states and the formation of thrombus anywhere in the body. From the serum and ascitic protein values, we can calculate the SAAG (serum protein-ascitic protein).

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: A patient comes with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following is not done?
questions.solution:
Platelet transfusion is not done in the case of active variceal bleeding unless coagulopathy is confirmed as the cause. Platelet transfusions are indicated only in patients with a platelet count of <50,000/microL  or in patients with evidence of microvascular bleeding.

Variceal hemorrhage is a medical emergency. Varices usually present with the acute onset large-volume haematemesis, the lower esophagus being the most common site for variceal bleeding.

The sites for portosystemic anastomosis are:

  • Left gastric vein to distal oesophageal veins: oesophageal and gastric variceal bleeding
  • Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: hemorrhoids and rectal bleeding
  • Left branch of the portal vein to Periumbilical veins: caput-medusae
  • The right branch of the portal vein to retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, lumbar, intercostal, and phrenic veins
  • Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures to Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures

Medical management of variceal bleeding includes blood transfusion (option B) and drug therapy with somatostatin analogs like octreotide (option C). Short-term antibiotics like ceftriaxone are known to decrease bacterial infection and increase survival.

Surgical measures are preferred if medical management fails. They include balloon tamponade, endoscopic banding (option D), transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS), portosystemic shunts, splenectomy, and gastric revascularization

Note: Sugiura procedure is the non-shunt surgical management of refractory oesophageal variceal bleeding. It is a procedure of de-vascularizing the distal esophagus and stomach.

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient with intractable ascites underwent a procedure as shown below. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt(TIPS) procedure with the viatorr device.

The main indication of TIPS is for variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment, and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anaesthetic, analgesia and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. Via the internal jugular vein and superior venacava, a guidewire is inserted into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The main early complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

Shunts for Portal Hypertension:

  • Non- Selective Shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted
    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective Shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt 

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A patient with liver cirrhosis is scheduled to undergo a laparotomy for a perforated appendix. According to the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score, which of the following parameters will you not use for this patient?
questions.solution:
Creatinine is not included in the Child–Turcotte–Pugh score or Child-Pugh scoring system. 

It is used to assess the surgical mortality of cirrhotic patients undergoing intra-abdominal operations.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a  component of MELD  score?
questions.solution:
In MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score, urea is not one of the components.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with gangrenous appendix underwent an appendicectomy. On the second postoperative day, he developed fever, chills, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain. Blood cultures revealed bacteremia and ultrasound abdomen revealed multiple hepatic abscesses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the setting of existing appendicitis, the above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of pylephlebitis (portal pyemia).

Pylephlebitis is thrombophlebitis of the portal venous system. It is a rare but very serious complication of intra-abdominal infections, such as gangrenous appendicitis, diverticulitis, etc. It spreads to the portal circulation via the mesenteric vein.

Clinical features are high fever, rigors, and jaundice and intrahepatic abscesses (often multiple) due to septicemia in the portal venous system. Treatment is with systemic antibiotics and percutaneous drainage of hepatic abscesses.

Option A: Peliosis hepatis is an uncommon vascular condition characterized by hemorrhagic dilatation of the hepatic sinusoids.

Option C: Hepatic necrotic nodules are usually small, solitary lesions, mainly located under the liver capsule of the right lobe. It is characterized by a necrotic central core surrounded by a dense hyalinized fibrotic capsule.

Option D: Melioidosis is an infectious disease caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei characterised by fever and multiple abscess formation in the lungs, liver, prostate, and spleen.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain and jaundice for the past 5 days. CT abdomen revealed the following finding and cultures of aspirate showed extensive bacterial growth. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Anchovy sauce pus is seen on aspiration of abscess
Fever with chills is the most common presenting complaint
Eschericia coli and Klebsiella species are the most common organisms implicated
Ascending infection from the biliary tract is the most common route of spread

questions.solution:
The given CT image shows cluster sign and the above clinical scenario is suggestive of pyogenic liver abscess. Anchovy sauce pus on aspiration is seen in amoebic liver abscess.

Pyogenic liver abscess is a polymicrobial infection seen more commonly in the elderly and immunocompromised. Ascending infection from the biliary tree (ascending suppurative cholangitis) is the most common route of spread.

The portal vein is the second most common source of infection leading to pylephlebitis (thrombophlebitis of the portal venous system causing portal pyemia) secondary to diverticulitis, appendicitis, pancreatitis, etc.

Organism:

  • Most common in western countries: Escherichia coli
  • Most common in Asian countries: Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • Most common in children suffering from the chronic granulomatous disease: Staphylococcus
  • Most common in gas-forming abscess: Klebsiella

Order of affected lobe: Right lobe (75%) > left lobe (20%) > caudate lobe (5%). Right lobe predilection might be due to preferential laminar blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding investigations in a pyogenic liver abscess is true?

choices.text: USG shows hypoechoic lesion with poorly defined borders
Elevated ALP is the most common abnormal LFT.

questions.solution:
Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level is the most common abnormal liver function test (LFT) in pyogenic liver abscess.

 Laboratory features in pyogenic liver abscess:

  • Non-specific findings such as leukocytosis, anemia
  • Elevated ALP (most common), elevated bilirubin levels, increased prothrombin time (PT) and INR (chronic infection).
  • Positive blood culture in 50% cases

Ultrasonography (USG) and computed tomography (CT) are investigations of choice . In ultrasound, pyogenic liver abscess appears as round or oval hypoechoic lesions with well defined borders and variable number of internal echoes. On CT, cluster sign is a feature of pyogenic hepatic abscesses.

questions.text: A healthy 55-year-old man presented with a 1-week history of fevers, chills, right upper quadrant tenderness, and hepatomegaly. CT was suggestive of a pyogenic liver abscess. Which of the following statements regarding management is true?

choices.text: Empiric IV antibiotic therapy is first line
Percutaneous drainage is not routinely done
Open drainage is done with T-tube placement
Resection of the affected lobe is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Empiric IV antibiotic therapy is the first-line treatment for pyogenic liver abscess.

Percutaneous drainage using a pigtail catheter is done routinely. It helps in the slow decompression of a cyst with viscous contents. It also has a lesser chance of dislodgement. Drainage tube catheter is placed under US/CT guidance into the liver abscess.

Surgical drainage using a laparoscopic or open approach is tried only when antibiotic therapy and percutaneous drainage fails. Open drainage is becoming less common at present. Liver resection is only occasionally required in severe hepatic destruction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old daily wage laborer presented with fever and abdominal pain for the past 1 week. Laboratory investigations showed anti-amoebic antibodies and CT abdomen showed the following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Anchovy sauce pus is seen on aspiration

questions.solution:
The patient most likely has an amoebic liver abscess. It is more common in males than females (10:1).

Risk factors include:

  • Males, 20-40 years of age
  • Heavy alcohol consumption - liver becomes more susceptible
  • Travel to an endemic area
  • Poverty and cramped living conditions
  • Impaired host immunity
  • Colonic infection

The most common sites for amoebic liver abscesses are liver and paracaecal areas. The aspirate shows a characteristic anchovy sauce pus.

Even though this disease process is secondary to a colonic infection, the presence of diarrhoea is unusual.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding amoebic liver abscess is false?

choices.text: Culture of the aspirate is positive.
The diagnosis is based on the detection of antiamebic antibodies.
Management mainly consists of conservative treatment with metronidazole.

questions.solution:
The culture of the amoebic abscess is usually sterile or negative.

The most useful laboratory evaluation is the measurement of cir­culating anti-amoebic antibodies, by enzyme immunoassay. The antibody can be present because of prior infection, and hence, detection of Entamoeba histolytica lectin antigen in the serum and liver abscess pus is more useful for acute infections than chronic infection.

Nuclear medicine studies, such as gallium scanning or technetium (99mTc)  liver scans, can be helpful in differentiating pyogenic from amebic abscesses because amebic abscesses typically do not contain leukocytes and therefore do not light up on these scans.

The mainstay of treatment for amebic abscesses is metronidazole (750 mg orally, three times daily for 10 days), which is curative. Luminal agents such as iodoquinol, paromomycin, and diloxanide furoate can be administered into the cysts.

questions.text: Which of the following are not indications for percutaneous aspiration in a patient with a suspected amoebic liver abscess?

choices.text: Failure to respond to medical therapy

questions.solution:
Percutaneous aspiration should be performed in amoebic liver abscess more than 5 cm. 

Indications for percutaneous aspiration in amoebic liver abscess are:

  • Large abscesses (>5 cm)
  • Lack of response to medical therapy (in 5 days)
  • Suspicion of superinfection
  • Abscesses of the left lobe of the liver at risk for rupture into the pericardium
  • Uncertain diagnosis

Laboratory investigations may reveal similar complete blood cell count and liver function test abnormalities in patients with amoebic liver abscesses and pyogenic liver abscesses. An elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level is seen in both and is not specific.

questions.text:
In the given image, which of the following structures are matched correctly?
  1. A-Ectocyst
  2. C-Scolex
  3. D-Brood capsules
  4. F-Endocyst
  5. H-Hydatid sand
questions.solution:
F -Endocyst and H-Hydatid sand are matched correctly.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of sheep and dogs as hosts. Humans are accidental hosts.

A hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrous capsule called pericyst that is derived from the host tissue.

The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst (inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in the passage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces.

The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk. 

The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts. The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.

questions.text: A patient was incidentally found to have a fluid filled cyst in his liver when he underwent a USG abdomen to check for renal calculi. It was later diagnosed as echinococcosis. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Rupture can lead to severe anaphylactic reaction
Echinococcus multilocularis is the most common causative agent

questions.solution:
Echinococcus granulosus is the most common causative agent in hydatid cysts, while Echinococcus multilocularis and Echinococcus ligartus account for a small number of cases.

Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, and humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human to human transmission.

The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic, until complications occur. The most common presenting symp­toms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are solitary.

questions.text: A young villager presents to the clinic with abdominal pain for the past 1 month. He mentions that he keeps sheep inside the house. On examination, you feel a firm mass in the right hypochondrium and a hepatic hydatid cyst is suspected. Which of the following investigations have the highest sensitivity in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa.

CT scan has an accuracy of 98% in the detection of hydatid cysts and higher sensitivity to demonstrate the daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts. 

The indirect hemagglutination test and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have a sensitivity of 80% overall and are the initial screening tests of choice.

The Casoni test is a skin test used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease and involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilised fluid from hydatid cysts/human cysts. A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive (immediate hypersensitivity). The test is positive in less than 50% of patients with hydatid disease elsewhere in the body and false-positive results are also common so it's not preferred.

Note: First/Initial imaging test is USG, best imaging test is CT scan

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have a hydatid cyst of the liver. If imaging studies are performed, all of the following signs will denote detached or collapsed cyst except____
questions.solution:
The double line sign is seen in an unruptured unilocular cyst with a double-layered wall representing the pericyst and endocyst.

Serpent sign is seen as wavy membranes within the cyst, on CT imaging.

Ball of wool sign is seen on ultrasound when the contents settle in the dependent portion of the cyst, as seen below.

The water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane which results in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily, on USG.

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. On examination, there is tenderness and enlargement of the liver. Abdominal ultrasound shows the following finding. As per the WHO classification of cystic echinococcosis, which class does this belong to?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound image is of active hydatid cyst with multiple septations and rosette or honeycomb appearance. As per the WHO classification of cystic echinococcosis (CE), it belongs to type 2 (CE2).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with right upper quadrant pain for the last 6 weeks. On examination, a firm mass is palpable in the right hypochondrium region. CECT abdomen shows a 6 cm cystic structure in the right lobe of the liver along with water lily sign. Which of the following is the ideal management for him?

choices.text: Careful observation with imaging every 6 months

questions.solution:
The given imaging finding on CECT is suggestive of class CE3A hydatid cyst disease of the liver.

The ideal management for type CE3A hydatid cyst of dimension >5cm is Albendazole therapy 400 mg twice daily and PAIR (puncture, aspiration, injection, and reaspiration) therapy.

When PAIR is contraindicated ( CE2, CE3B), surgical resection involving laparoscopic or open complete cystectomy with instillation of a scolicidal agent is preferred and is usually curative. If complete cystectomy is not possible, then anatomic liver resection can be undertaken.

Careful observation and ultrasound evaluation every 6 months are recommended CE4 and CE5 categories.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for performing PAIR technique in hydatid cyst disease?

choices.text: Pregnant woman with CE1 hydatid cyst
Cyst > 5 cm in different liver segments

questions.solution:
A hydatid cyst with honeycomb appearance (CE2) is a contraindication for PAIR (Puncture-Aspiration-Injection-Reaspiration). 

PAIR is unlikely to be successful in CE2 due to the presence of multiple internal septa.

The PAIR technique is performed using either ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) guidance. 

It involves aspiration of the cyst contents via a special cannula, followed by injection of a scolicidal agent for at least 15 minutes, and then reaspiration of the cystic contents. This is repeated until the return is clear. An initial course of albendazole is administered before the procedure. 

When PAIR is contraindicated, surgical resection involving laparoscopic or open complete cystectomy with instillation of a scolicidal agent is preferred and is usually curative. If complete cystectomy is not possible, then anatomic liver resection can be undertaken.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: A dog trainer presented to the hospital with a history of pain in the upper part of the abdomen. The surgeon decides to perform a percutaneous aspiration, injection, and reaspiration (PAIR) of the cyst after a 6 cm single hydatid cyst was detected. All of the following can be used as scolicidal agents in this procedure except?
questions.solution:
Formalin is not used as a scolicidal agent since it causes sclerosing cholangitis. 

Scolicidal agents (used to avoid dissemination of parasite during surgery):

  • Hypertonic saline 
  • Cetrimide 
  • Alcohol
  • Sodium hypochlorite
  • Povidone-iodine

questions.text: Capitonnage is used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Capitonnage is used in the treatment of hydatid cyst disease. It is the spiral suturing of the cavity upward from the base of the cavity to the edge of the cyst wall.

Pyogenic liver abscess is treated with antibiotics and percutaneous drainage.

Hepatic tuberculosis is treated with quadruple therapy (isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol)

questions.text: Which of the following do not cause peliosis hepatis?
questions.solution:
Analgesics will not cause peliosis hepatis.

Peliosis hepatis is an uncommon vascular condition characterized by hemorrhagic dilatation of the hepatic sinusoids. Conditions causing peliosis hepatis are: 

  1. Bartonella henselae infection, tuberculosis, and human immunodeficiency virus
  2. Use of anabolic steroids
  3. Immunosuppressants such as 6-mercaptopurine, azathioprine, methotrexate, and tamoxifen
  4. X-linked myotubular myopathy

Biopsy showing hemorrhagic dilatation:

Often an incidental finding, many patients present without symptoms. Less frequently, patients may present with signs more consistent with hepatobiliary pathology such as right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension.

Laboratory studies, such as LFT may or may not demonstrate changes. CT or MRI angiography often demonstrates contrast accumulating within the parenchyma itself or the sinusoids. A biopsy is the best modality to confirm the diagnosis.
